description: Primes p for which the period of the reciprocal 1/p is (p-1)/3.
comments: Cyclic numbers of the third degree (or third order): the reciprocals of these numbers belong to one of three different cycles. Each cycle has (number-1)/3 digits.All primes p except 2 or 5 have a reciprocal with period which divides p-1.
references: Richards, Stephen P., A NUMBER FOR YOUR THOUGHTS, 1982, 1984, Box 501, New Providence, NJ, 07974, ISBN 0-9608224-0-2.
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n=1..1000
Index entries for sequences related to decimal expansion of 1/n
mathematica: LP[ n_Integer ] := (ds = Divisors[ n - 1 ]; Take[ ds, Position[ PowerMod[ 10, ds, n ], 1 ][ [ 1, 1 ] ] ][ [ -1 ] ]); CL[ n_Integer ] := (n - 1)/LP[ n ]; Select[ Range[ 7, 7500 ], PrimeQ[ # ] && CL[ # ] == 3 & ]f[n_Integer] := Block[{ds = Divisors[n - 1]}, (n - 1)/Take[ ds, Position[ PowerMod[ 10, ds, n], 1] [[1, 1]]] [[ -1]]]; Select[ Prime[ Range[4, 700]], f[ # ] == 3 &] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Sep 14 2004 *)
author: Don Willard (dwillard(AT)prairie.cc.il.us), Jun 05 2000
extensions: More terms from _Robert G. Wilson v_, Aug 02 2000
Edited by _N. J. A. Sloane_ at the suggestion of _Andrew Plewe_, May 27 2007
